Page-Turner

“The Sympathizer,” A harrowing memoir exploring identity during the Vietnam War

By Karun Ellango, Robert Eisenman, Dipto Saha

June 12,2010

  •

Following the North Vietnamese takeover of South Vietnam, many South Vietnamese people fled their country to live new lives in the United States. They became stateless refugees, struggling to hold on to their national identity while attempting to assimilate to America. The narrator, who was born in Vietnam but raised in America, begins to understand why the North Vietnamese adopted communism, going against everything that he learned from his superiors. The narrator struggles to hide his political ideologies, while maintaining his nationalistic facade.

Nguyen masterfully crafts a novel from the viewpoint of the underrepresented sympathizers of North Vietnam. Most of the media that is based on the Vietnamese war focuses on the American experience and involvement of the war. Most Americans grew up watching movies of cigarette-smoking, sunglass-wearing American soldiers firing machine guns into a jungle of North Vietna guerilla fighters. Instead, Nguyen writes about the espionage and tactical battle that went on behind the gun fights. Nguyen shows the psychological and physical stress of being a double agent. For instance, the narrator takes part in two assassinations and instantly regrets his murders. His conscience becomes torn and he struggles to live through his crushing guilt.

The story is told through the lens of an anonymous narrator, and begins with a flashback to the state of South Vietnam in 1975, right near the fall of the state and the unification under the Socialist Republic of Vietnam following the successful takeover by the North Vietnamese. Here, fleeing South Vietnamese are executed, but a few lucky escape through ways such as an American rescue plane that Nguyen is forced to give to high ranking South Vietnamese Army officials to maintain his cover.

Throughout the entire story, the narrator struggles with the duality of his being. He is a spy for the North Vietnamese, yet feels terrible witnessing the torture of South Vietnamese by the communists. The narrator constantly struggles with his French and Vietnamese identity. Later in the novel, he continuously struggles with his Vietnamese identity while living in The United States, in admiration of the advancement of the country but annoyed by the air of superiority everywhere around the country.

Whether in ideology or loyalty, the narrator struggles to find either side as “right”. He is thrilled to see the downfall of the South Vietnamese, but understands the experiences of his fellow South Vietnamese soldiers whose families were ravaged by the communists. While his purpose is to help the North Vietnamese, he also feels grateful to the South Vietnamese general who raised him to become the man he is. The narrator also finds himself with conflicting loyalties between his North Vietnamese handler, Man, and his South Vietnamese friend Bon.

Nguyen is able to effectively develop the complexity of the duality of the narrators beings and his relationship with the others, while filling all holes and leaving the reader without any confusion in how they came to be. Despite this, the narrator is able to make the story a rollercoaster of emotions, and the story becomes anything but the expected.

The struggles with identity within oneself draws parallels with Barack Obama’s “Dreams from my father.” Former U.S. President Obama, who is also of mixed heritage, experienced different kinds of prejudice while in the lands of his mother’s and his father’s heritage. Whichever place both narrators go, different kinds of inner struggles meet them. However, whereas the focus of Obama’s inner struggle was more race related, the narrator in “The Sympathizer focused more on ideology and cultural differences.

In America, the narrator attempts to rekindle his nationalist identity. He mentioned that America only reminded him of the things that he loved in Vietnam. Nguyen humanizes the characters through their struggle of assimilating to American culture. Man and the narrator struggle to gain a foothold in America and have to resort to getting a sponsor from a church. They struggle to find work and attain a greater education. In this part of the novel, Nguyen writes in a comedic tone. Nguyen essentially writes a social commentary on American culture and occasionally cracks a joke. This addition of comedy feels out of place, as it offsets the vehement introduction. It also felt strange to transition from the social commentary to the proposed plot of a revolution in Vietnam.

  • Karun, Robert and Dipto are all Seniors at the Bronx High School of Science
